natural problem: Simplify the following expression: $(x^5+x^4+x+10)-(x^5+2x^4-x^3+12).$ Express your answer as a polynomial with the degrees of the terms in decreasing order.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 5 + x powr 4 + x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 + 2 * (x powr 4) - x powr 3 + 12"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x - Q x = - (x powr 4) + x powr 3 + x - 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify the following expression: $(x^5+x^4+x+10)-(x^5+2x^4-x^3+12).$ Express your answer as a polynomial with the degrees of the terms in decreasing order. The final Answer is -x^4+x^3+x-2
 ### Proof
 We have \begin{align} &(x^5+x^4+x+10)-(x^5+2x^4-x^3+12)\\ &=(1-1)x^5+(1-2)x^4+(0-(-1))x^3+(1-0)x+(10-12)\\ &=\boxed{-x^4+x^3+x-2} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 5 + x powr 4 + x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 5 + 2 * (x powr 4) - x powr 3 + 12"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x - Q x = - (x powr 4) + x powr 3 + x - 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For all real numbers x, let P(x) be $x^5 + x^4 + x + 10$ and Q(x) be $x^5 + 2x^4 - x^3 + 12$. Show that for all x, the difference P(x) - Q(x) is equal to $-x^4 + x^3 + x - 2$.

fixes x :: real
shows  "(x powr 5 + x powr 4 + x + 10) - (x powr 5 + 2 * x powr 4 - x powr 3 + 12) = -x powr 4 + x powr 3 + x - 2"
a_1.formal solution:

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "(x powr 5 + x powr 4 + x + 10) - (x powr 5 + 2 * x powr 4 - x powr 3 + 12) = -x powr 4 + x powr 3 + x - 2"
